unnormalised: AIIMS Delhi reports a surge in cases related to gastroenterological disorders during the monsoon season. Dr. R.K. Sharma, Head of the Gastroenterology Department, highlighted a 20% increase in patients presenting with symptoms like diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain compared to the pre-monsoon period. The hospital's outpatient department (OPD) has seen a daily influx of approximately 150-200 patients seeking treatment for various gastrointestinal ailments.
normalised: A-I-I-M-S Delhi reports a surge in cases related to gastroenterological disorders during the monsoon season. Doctor R.K. Sharma, Head of the Gastroenterology Department, highlighted a twenty percent increase in patients presenting with symptoms like diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain compared to the pre-monsoon period. The hospital's outpatient department (O-P-D) has seen a daily influx of approximately one hundred and fifty to two hundred patients seeking treatment for various gastrointestinal ailments.

unnormalised: "The unhygienic conditions prevalent during the monsoon, coupled with the consumption of contaminated food and water, are major contributing factors," explained Dr. Sharma. The most commonly diagnosed conditions include acute gastroenteritis, typhoid fever, and hepatitis A. He further advised citizens to avoid street food, consume boiled water, and maintain proper hygiene to prevent infection. A recent study published in the 'Indian Journal of Gastroenterology' also supports these findings, linking seasonal variations to the incidence of infectious gastrointestinal diseases.

unnormalised: In response to the increased demand, AIIMS has prepone-d the timings of its gastrointestinal clinic and increased the number of beds allocated to the gastroenterology ward by 30. The hospital has also launched a public awareness campaign, disseminating information through social media and local newspapers, focusing on preventive measures and early detection. The campaign includes educational materials in both Hindi and English, accessible on the AIIMS website and distributed at community health centers.

unnormalised: The hospital is also conducting research on the prevalence and antibiotic resistance patterns of common gastrointestinal pathogens in the region. Initial findings suggest a rising resistance to commonly used antibiotics like ciprofloxacin and azithromycin. The results of this research will inform treatment guidelines and help develop strategies to combat antibiotic resistance. The hospital encourages citizens to be vigilant and proactive in protecting their health during the monsoon season.
